6th Annual International Conference on Applied Category Theory (ACT2023)

July 31 - August 4, 2023

https://act2023.github.io/

The Sixth International Conference on Applied Category Theory will take place at the University of Maryland from 31 July to 4 August 2023, preceded by the Adjoint School 2023 from 24 to 28 July. This conference follows previous events at Strathclyde (UK), Cambridge (UK), Cambridge (MA), Oxford (UK) and Leiden (NL).

Applied category theory is important to a growing community of researchers who study computer science, logic, engineering, physics, biology, chemistry, social science, systems, linguistics and other subjects using category-theoretic tools. The background and experience of our members is as varied as the systems being studied. The goal of the Applied Category Theory conference series is to bring researchers together, strengthen the applied category theory community, disseminate the latest results, and facilitate further development of the field.

SUBMISSIONS

We accept submissions in English of original research papers, talks about work accepted/ submitted/published elsewhere, and demonstrations of relevant software. Accepted original research papers will be published in a proceedings volume. The conference will include an industry showcase event and community meeting. We particularly encourage people from
underrepresented groups to submit their work and the organizers are committed to non-discrimination, equity, and inclusion.

Original research papers intended for conference proceedings should present original, high-quality work in the style of a computer science conference paper (up to 12 pages, not counting the bibliography; more detailed parts of proofs may be included in an appendix for the convenience of the reviewers). Please use the EPTCS style files available at

http://style.eptcs.org

Such submissions should not be an abridged version of an existing journal article although pre-submission arXiv preprints are permitted. These submissions will be adjudicated for both a talk and publication in the conference proceedings.

IMPORTANT DATES

The following dates are all in 2023, and Anywhere On Earth.

  • Submission Deadline: Wednesday 3 May

  • Author Notification: Wednesday 7 June

  • Camera-ready version due: Tuesday 27 June

  • Conference begins: 31 July

Some news about submitting your talks to ACT2023:

Submission formats:

  1. Conference Papers should present original, high-quality work in the style of a computer science conference paper (up to 12 pages, not counting the bibliography; more detailed parts of proofs may be included in an appendix for the convenience of the reviewers). Such submissions should not be an abridged version of an existing journal article although pre-submission arXiv preprints are permitted. These submissions will be adjudicated for both a talk and publication in the conference proceedings.

  2. Talk proposals not to be published in the proceedings, e.g. about work accepted/submitted/published elsewhere, should be submitted as abstracts, one or two pages long. Authors are encouraged to include links to any full versions of their papers, preprints or manuscripts. The purpose of the abstract is to provide a basis for determining the topics and quality of the anticipated presentation.

  3. Software demonstration proposals should also be submitted as abstracts, one or two pages. The purpose of the abstract is to provide the program committee with enough information to assess the content of the demonstration.

The original conference papers will ultimately be published with EPTCS, and authors are advised to use the style files available at style.eptcs.org.

DATES AND DEADLINES

Please submit your papers and talk proposals at: OpenReview
<https://openreview.net/group?id=AppliedCategoryTheory.org/ACT/2023/Conference>.

You will need to create an account or log in. Please tell OpenReview as
much as you can about yourself, and your past papers, because it uses this to automatically calculate conflict of interest. (Reviewing is
single-blind, and we are not making public the reviews, reviewer names, the discussions nor the list of under-review submissions. This is the same as previous instances of ACT.) The exact deadline time on these dates is given by anywhere on earth <http://www.ieee802.org/16/aoe.html> (AoE).

Papers and Abstracts Due 3 May 2023
Author Notification 7 June 2023
Conference 31 July – 4 August 2023

Limited financial support will be available for travel. Priority will be

reasons, and we will accommodate that in the programme via remote

Hi, A couple of people had problems with registering for openreview, so we will leave the submission site open until 4 May AOE (ie 5 May 1200 UTC). Anyone who had trouble can retry at open review. Do let me know of any problems. Thanks to all those who already submitted!

I noticed that there are several PhD students on the editorial board, many of which with the same supervisor. I understand that the "ACT community" is very young, but isn't this unusual for academic conferences? I think that this also happened the year prior. Does anyone on the steering committee care to comment on this?
Hi Cole, before I reply, can I double-check, are you referring to the ACT 2023 programme committee rather than editorial board? Or maybe you're talking about a different thing.

Sam Staton said:

Hi Cole, before I reply, can I double-check, are you referring to the ACT 2023 programme committee rather than editorial board? Or maybe you're talking about a different thing.

yes sorry I mean the "Program Committee"

Thanks. To be clear, we plan to make sure that every submission will be looked at by the more experienced people on the committee. Perhaps that's what you were concerned about, which is definitely a valid concern.

Some bigger conferences do have an explicit hierarchy in the PC, which includes students at some levels (e.g. I think ICML etc do this). I agree that would be unusual in TCS. But putting together a PC is a bit complicated.
Happy to chat about it more some time.

My concern is more that if there are no clear rules about how the program committee is decided, then a professor can have disproportionate influence on the community by appointing their own students to the program committee: elevating themselves, their students and their research disproportionately.

This is especially bad for students whose supervisors are not involved in the conference, because then, not only will they be less likely to subreview papers, but their influence will be made even lower in proportion to groups where multiple members are on the committee.

I find it kind of strange, that to my knowledge, last year in my research group no one subreviewed any papers for the conference, but my fellow PhD students at other research groups where most likely sending papers to their colleagues to subreview for them! Admittedly, this may be a problem with the structure of our group, but I think it would be good if this sort of thing could be mediated by the senior members of the comittee.

This seems kind of exclusionary. Given that the conference is supposed to broadly represent applied category theory as a discipline, I think it would be better if the criteria were made clear. And moreover, I think it is important that people from all groups who are working on applied category theory are equally represented in deciding which papers are accepted, and thus, to shape the future of the community.

Of course, these things are usually decided by professors behind closed doors, which I am not privy to as a PhD student, but the fact that there are PhD students on the program comittee is very unusual.

This is just my opinion as a PhD student, and I have no right to have any influence over the direction of the conference, of course. I am not trying to be critical or mean or anything and I hope that this conference goes really well and is great fun as usual! :)
Make :clap: the :clap: review :clap: process :clap: open
Seconded, I would be happy for my reviews to be public, although I understand that not everyone who signed up to review for this particular conference would feel the same way.

By the way I share ALL of your concerns. And besides the usual 'let's talk about it' I believe the only solution is to make the whole review process open. If reviewers have to 'own' the review, you can be sure that stuff like 'doing favors'/'reading only superficially'/'not caring enough' would have a completely different weight. Coming from one of the most mafia-infested regions in the world I know for a fact that the sort of behavior you fear thrives when it can't be seen.

In the past (not at ACT fortunately!) I literally received 2-line reviews that were like "Score: -2/ Review:I am not by any means an expert in this field, but this doesn't sound right." good luck at pulling some deranged shit like this when everyone can read you and knows your name.

Thanks Cole. I know what you mean, I've felt upset about things like this before too. Perhaps Christina and I can make public the method we used to put together the PC, since we did try to think about these kinds of issue.
As for open reviews. We are using OpenReview but not in open mode this year. Something to discuss further for 2024 perhaps. I can see pros and cons.

Sam Staton said:

Perhaps Christina and I can make public the method we used to put together the PC, since we did try to think about these kinds of issue.

I would gladly read it
The Steering Board for the ACT conferences should probably get involved in any big decisions about how refereeing works in these conferences. That's Bob Coecke, Dorette Pronk, David Spivak and me.

I'm not saying we should boss around everyone else - but we are the people who stay around from year to year, while the Organizing Committee varies from year to year, so if we're trying to make decisions that will apply next year, and the years after that, it's good to get the Steering Committee involved.

Anyway, as a start I think it'll be great to hear @Sam Staton and @Christina Vasilakopoulou say something about how they chose the Program Committee. (I'm not saying they have to do this publicly here, but maybe other people want that, and I certainly don't mind it.)

Does the ACT conference need so many referees that we/they need professors and also their grad students to serve as referees? Are there kinds of people who should be on the Program Committee but aren't? Are there measures in place to reduce the tendency for groups of people who know each other to push their friends forwards while being tougher on other people? Etc. - these seem like good questions.
Thanks John. Christina and I did take great care over the PC and used various methods to avoid biases. Many conferences have a "PC report" at the event, is that a good idea?
I think part of the point of these PC reports is to discuss trends, ideas etc with the SC and perhaps the wider community.

In brief for now, since we're also busy trying to work out the review assignments right now: but relating to the concern just raised, there are three students on the PC this year, out of 47 people; this is fewer students than last year; their advisors are not on the PC this year and didn't push anything at all this year. Hope that sounds reasonable.

Wow, great! It sounds like the problem of having a professor and a bunch of their students on the program committee is almost gone now! I think this is quite different from previous years, when the ACT community seemed so small and tight-knit that this problem seemed hard to avoid.

I agree, though, that when you're done with your work and have had a weekend or two to recover, a "PC report" would be great. The most interesting aspects to me would be problems that you had to work to overcome, and problems you feel you didn't succeed in overcoming - so we can try to do better next year.

Thanks for all the opinions above, these things and concerns are indeed very important to discuss. After the process is over, we will write more details on a PC report and then have further discussions!

I think you make some good points in favor of open review and I sympathize with your point of view. How would you propose incentivizing people to review when the budget is about 0? I worry that having totally public reviews will make it so less people agree to review.

Another problem is if the author of a submission holds a lot of sway, a grad student may not want to publicly leave them a bad review. Especially if it is a person who has some level of control over their future.
And also if a professor leaves a bad review for a student it could be very cruel.

I share Jade's concern. Being anonymous as a reviewer means I can be frank and direct and not apologetic or shy about my opinions.
I wouldn't be comfortable writing reviews with my full name on it and then go on about meeting the people at the conference. I fear it would steer petty hostilities, or worse, make reviews dull just to be nice.

What has to be fought is people not doing their job as reviewers, or being unnecessarily harsh. Deanonymizing reviews can have this effect but also other undesired side effects.

I believe one of the shades of “open review” is to have the reviews publicly readable, but still anonymous. This comes with its own problems but it would alleviate some of the ones just mentioned.
